animal.description:
Roo is a very playful girl who absolutely loves hanging out with the fam! At 2 years young, Roo has plenty to learn. Roo will need an experienced bully breed owner. 

Roo prefers the company of her family and is shy when meeting new people, but warms up quickly when given space and time to adjust to them. 

Roo is great with older children who respect her space. Roo gets along with big and small dogs. Roo is a little too interested in cats so a home without cats is recommended.  

Roo recently had ACL surgery so she will need to take it easy for a few more months, however she’s healing nicely. 

Roo walks well on leash and loves to play with her toys. She’s a sweet girl who will win over your heart with her beautiful champagne coat and light eyes. Roo needs an active home where she can go on daily jobs or hikes. Roo is described as being easy to love and extremely affectionate. Roo’s only vice is she hates being left alone, so she needs someone who can work her through her insecurities. She’d be happiest with a homebody who works part time or works from home.

Roo would make the perfect guard dog for someone who lives alone or someone who doesn’t really have a huge circle of friends that come over frequently.  Reach out today to meet this beautiful girl. Roo is as loyal as they come. 

Roo will be attending a training program so she will have the foundations for being an even better version of herself. We just need her forever family to be ready and willing to continue working with her.

animal.description:
PLEASE READ THE ENTIRE BIO ON THIS DOG BEFORE REQUESTING AN APPLICATION.  MANY OF OUR DOGS HAVE STRICT REQUIREMENTS FOR THEIR ADOPTION.
SPECIFIC REQUIREMENTS FOR RUPERT'S ADOPTION:

1.  CANNOT LIVE IN AN APARTMENT.

2.  NO CHILDREN UNDER 12.

5 year old male Chiweenie, about 9 pounds. Rupert came into rescue 3 years ago completely feral. As any feral pooch, time and consistency has turned him into a real LOVE BUG! He is as normal a dog as any other, but he does have a few residual fear issues occasionally. He tends to bark at strangers coming into the house and alerts when someone is in the driveway. He lives with many dogs, but would love to have his own person. He takes time to warm up to strangers. Loves to sleep under the covers and will follow you around the house, even to the bathroom! He sticks to his foster like glue. Respectful older children or adult only household would be best. 

Adoption contract and fee applies.  All adoptable dogs can be met at adoption events hosted every weekend. For a list of scheduled events go to: https://www.facebook.com/SmidgetRescue/events .  Smidget Rescue is not a shelter, and dogs cannot be seen at the Rescue location. All dogs are fostered throughout the Puget Sound area and are brought to the events where they can be met by prospective adopters. Additional pictures of adoptable dogs can be seen at: https://www.facebook.com/SmidgetRescue/photos_stream?tab=photos_albums.   All adoptable dogs are spayed or neutered at 6 months of age or older, and always before being placed in their new homes.  APPLICATIONS CAN BE OBTAINED BY EMAIL ONLY. Adoption process includes application, meet & greet, home visit and reference check. Email Jamie at smidgetrescue@hotmail.com or click on the CONTACT link on this page.  PLEASE DOUBLE CHECK YOUR EMAIL ADDRESS BEFORE SENDING.  We get a fair number of incorrect emails and Jamie is not able to contact potential adopters.  Notice:  We do not ship dogs out of state.  If you live within a five-hour radius of Seattle, WA, (such as Portland, Vancouver B.C., etc.), we can arrange for a home visit.  If your home seems like a great fit for the dog you would like to adopt, you must then drive to meet the dog at one of our weekend events or at the fosters home.

animal.breeds_label: Black Labrador Retriever & English Pointer Mix
animal.description:
You can fill out an adoption application online on our official website.If interested in any of our animals for adoption, or to foster an animal, please fill out the respective application here to get the process started. Visit our FAQ webpage for commonly asked questions about our adoption/foster process.

'Won't you please pay attention to me? I just want to play!'
Meet Prince, an active 9 year old Black Labrador Retriever / English Pointer mix. Poor Prince was confined to an apartment with no socialization and little attention because the family lost interest in him. LDDR agreed to take Prince and find the right home for him. He is now receiving lots of playtime and TLC in his foster home while waiting for a forever home.
Prince is your typical busy dog that will do best in a home with an adopter who is willing to work with him to teach him some proper manners. He can be a bit wary of unknown people and would need slow introductions to someone he doesn't know. A fenced yard would be ideal to play ball, as that's his favorite thing to do. Prince walks well on a leash except when a car goes by. He currently has a desire to chase moving cars. He is perfectly house trained and will bark at the door to let you know he needs to go out, and he will bark at the door to come back in, too. Prince is ok with most dogs when properly introduced, but he will grumble if a dog gets too chummy or rude.
For more information or questions, email Tim at tmb611@msn.com.
Click here to watch a video of Prince.Last Day Dog Rescue now microchips all animals before adoption. Microchips are implanted between the animals shoulder blades and are a permanent form of identification. The microchips are registered to Last Day Dog Rescue with the adopter's info added once adopted. If the animal is ever lost and slips his/her collar/tags the microchip allows the finder to know who to contact if scanned for a microchip. Animals MUST still have a collar with tags on at all times. Per our contract, we take all our animals back if for any reason you can't keep your adopted animal.

Please understand the statements about this animal are based upon the foster home's evaluation of the animal. The animal might behave differently (negatively or positively) in your home. While the animal might be good with the current foster's dogs, cats, children, etc., it may not be with your animal(s) or children. The animal may be housebroken or litter trained in the home of the foster but may relapse in your home. The animal is represented to the public as it performs in the foster home and any statements made regarding the animal are conditional to that foster home setting. Please understand that statements made regarding this animal are simply overviews and are not guaranteed.

The Petfinder.com system requires that we choose a predominant breed or breed mix for our animals. Visual breed identification in animals is unreliable so for most of the animals we are only guessing at predominant breed or breed mix. We get to know each animal as an individual and will do our best to describe each of our animals based on personality, not by breed label.

Thank you for looking through our list of animals needing forever homes and choosing rescue first. We appreciate you stopping by.

animal.description:
Please read our adoption requirements at http://gsrne.org/requirements-for-adopting-from-gsrne before contacting us about this dog.
Freya seems to be always smiling, and meeting people is her 
specialty.  She greets everyone with affection and enjoys getting 
praise and attention, making visitors feel like old friends.
She came into GSRNE in June, after her owner called and said he 
and his wife had gotten a divorce and were each moving to 
housing where dogs were not allowed.  Their two dogs, 5 ½ years 
old, had been littermates and together their whole lives.  He was 
hoping they could stay together, but we explained that it’s 
difficult to find adopters who can take two dogs at once.  We were
very lucky to have a foster home who would do that, but we 
learned that the two dogs would probably do better if separated.
Freya is not really interested in toys and actually buried the ones 
she was given.  Her favorite game was to chase after her brother, 
Aries, and nip at his heels while he chased his favorite toy, a 
Frisbee.  That didn’t seem to bother Aries, and Freya continued to 
practice her herding skills.
There were two cats in the home, and our evaluator witnessed 
their interactions with Freya, who was comfortable having them 
around.  She is not tolerant of other dogs, though, except for her 
brother.  When there were other dogs in the neighboring fenced 
yard, she would rush to bark at them through the fence and try to
fence fight.  She is indifferent about going for walks, but will 
gladly accompany you if that’s what you want to do.
When she came into GSRNE, Freya was overweight and trimmed 
down nicely while in foster care.  Her original owner told us that 
she had been taught to ring a bell on the door knob or bark when 
she needed to go out.  When outside in the fenced yard, Freya is 
more interested in flying insects than most dogs seem to be.  
Once she locks in on one, she’ll chase it all around until it flies out
of sight.
Freya is ready for her forever home with an adopter who will 
appreciate all the love she has to give and who will give her lots 
of love and affection in return.

animal.description:
Meet Mazerati! He is a sweet boy who can take some time to trust you, but once he does, he is very lovable. He will need owners who are active and can provide lots of training and socialization. He needs adults only and no kids at all. He needs owners that can be firm with him as he will listen better to commands. He is a sensitive boy, so positive reinforcement is really important to him. He is still learning to ride well in a car and not pull on the leash. 




Foster notes:
Mazzy is a very lovable and loving dog with a lot of potential. Given his probable lack of socialization and fear of strangers, we think he would be best in an adult-only household, and with someone who understands and will work with a dog who shows some signs of fear/aggression. He needs someone with a lot of patience who is willing to put in the time and energy to teach him rules and boundaries. He improved substantially over just a couple of weeks with regular training and exercise, but he needs firm guidance, consistency, and love. 

What he loves:
He loves squeaky toys and hard chew toys, but essentially, he loves any and all food. He loves cuddling and sleeping in the bed and preventing you from making the bed. He loves laying by your feet while you work, and loves long hikes outside. If he has a chance to be off-leash, he has the goofiest zoomies. He loves to roll in cow pies (beware!) and he loves sticking his head out of the car windows.

What he knows:
He knows "sit, "paw, a little bit of "stay and "wait. He is pretty good on the leash unless he is fearful or trying to chase a critter. He has not stolen any food off the table, but he likely would if given the opportunity.

Other dogs:
He loves playing with other dogs, but if the other dog shows any signs of aggression or defensiveness, he will likely reciprocate . So he would probably do best hanging out with a familiar dog friend who isn't very reactive. He is also reactive on the leash, so narrow trails and hallways are areas to pay attention to.

Strangers:
He used to try to run away from every stranger with his tail between his legs, and he continues to be fearful, especially of larger groups of people. But he has gotten much better and will now stand quietly (albeit a bit warily) and let people pass on hiking trails. He is also terrified of bicycles and skateboards, but has gotten better with them as well. He just hasn't gotten enough socialization in his life, but he will continue to improve.

Potty training: He marked in our house several times (no pooping accidents), but it is likely due to previous dog pee smells. In a different home, he did not have a single peeing incident. He is probably not 100%, but seems like he gets the general idea. 

Other notes:
Even though he is scared of men more than women, he tends to get used to them as long as they are good with dogs. He definitely loved both of us (one female, one male) and slept in our bed every night. Unfortunately, he did show some fear/aggression towards one male roommate, and the situation worsened with time. Thus, we recommend that all household members are fairly experienced with dogs and/or meet him before taking him home. 
He would do really well in a home with its own large yard where he can play with toys, but he definitely needs plenty of exercise. He really enjoys long hikes, and we have taken him to Wildcat Canyon many times. He will chase wildlife if you're not careful! He also seems to become quite energetic and hyper in the evening time - perhaps because he doesn't enjoy daytime neighborhood walks if lots of people are out and about. He had a tendency to randomly pick things, like pillows or tables, and start chewing, but if he has plenty of toys he'll be fine!

**My adoption fee is one half off! Adoption fee: $200.**

animal.description:
Aries lives to run, play and go for walks....he’s an active boy and 
will bring you a toy when you first meet him.  He’s not interested 
in being petted or fussed over until he gets to know you really 
well, and then he’ll show you the warm and fuzzy side to his 
personality.
He came into GSRNE in June, 2020, after his owner called and said
he and his wife had gotten a divorce and were each moving to 
housing where dogs were not allowed.  Their two dogs had been littermates and together their whole lives.  He was 
hoping they could stay together, but we explained that it’s 
difficult to find adopters who can take two dogs at once.  We were
very lucky to have a foster home who would do that, but we 
learned that the two dogs would probably do better if separated.
Aries especially loves his Frisbee but will also dash off after a ball 
or other toy you throw for him to retrieve.  He rushes back, eyes 
dancing, and eager to chase after it again.  His enthusiasm for 
jumping to catch the Frisbee did lead to an injury, causing trauma
to his sciatic nerve when he landed wrong.  He’s been through 
physical therapy and acupuncture and is back to running, playing 
fetch and going for walks, which is another favorite activity.  No 
more high jumps for him, though, and he’s just as happy running 
after ground balls and chasing the Frisbee at ground level.
Walks should be part of his daily routine, as he looks forward to 
them and needs that kind of exercise.  He weighed 110 pounds 
when he came into GSRNE, and his foster Dad helped him slim 
down to 90 pounds by walking twice a day as well as measuring 
his food consistently.  He’s not interested in playing with other 
dogs and would not enjoy a dog park.  He did live with two cats, 
though, and got along well with them.
If you’re looking for an active boy who will want to be by your side
and just hang out in the evenings, Aries might be just the dog for 
you!

animal.description:
****Please do not send us inquiries/emails asking if this puppy is still available; if a dog/puppy is still listed on Petfinder, we are still accepting applications for them. See the bottom of this bio for more FAQs regarding our adoption process before emailing.****

Name: Daisy Mae

Age: approximately 11 years old

Current Weight: 70 lbs

Rescued from: Texas

Health: up to date on required vaccines, spayed

Adoption fee: $300

Daisy Mae was rescued from an area where there is an abundance of homeless dogs, and not a lot of shelter space for them to go while they wait for their forever homes. Daisy Mae is very sweet, mellow and low-key. She has a little bit of a hard time going up the stairs due to her age and also seems to be a little hard of hearing. It would be great if she could find a family to give her love and attention in her golden years! It would be great if her adopters had a nice yard where she could wander around and relax while enjoying the outdoors, which she loves!

Daisy Mae will be arriving at SNARR's Adoption Center in Brewster, NY once she has a foster or adopter readying to bring her home! To apply to adopt or foster her, fill out an application at www.snarrnortheast.org/applications.

-------------------------------------------------------
FAQs -- PLEASE READ ALL BEFORE EMAILING

**Please note that SNARR NE is a volunteer-based organization. While our volunteers will try to respond to you as quickly as possible, it is helpful if you review the following information about our adoption process before emailing:**

- LISTED BREED(S) & AGE: We are taking our best guess on age, breed, and size when fully grown, based on the puppy's/dog's physical appearance and what we might have learned about one or both parents depending on the situation. *NOTE* We rarely know a dog's exact age, nor are we able to tell the true or full breed mix of dogs as our information is limited most of the time. Because we often do not have access to medical records at the time that we are posting dogs to Petfinder, so there are sometimes discrepancies between what is posted on Petfinder and what might be listed on a dog's medical records.

- SNARR'S ADOPTION PROCESS: The first step in adopting or meeting a SNARR dog/puppy is to fill out an application at www.snarrnortheast.org/applications. Once we receive your application, one of our adoption application processors will contact you, review our adoption process with you, and answer any additional questions you may have. **We do not go on a first-come-first-serve basis for adoptions, but on best fit for a family and most importantly the puppy or dog.**

- MEETING ADOPTABLE DOGS: Meet and greets will not be scheduled until after your adoption application has been fully processed by one of our adoption processors.

- APPLYING ONLINE: If you fill out an online application, please do so from a computer (not a mobile device), make sure you answer ALL the questions in as much detail as possible, and that you receive a confirmation email. If you do not receive a confirmation email, that means we did NOT receive your application.

- PUPPIES: We do suggest listing a 1st, 2nd and 3rd choice on your application if applying for a puppy with several litter mates.

- ADOPTION FEES:  $495 for puppies / $425 for adults / Adoption Fees for Seniors, Special Needs and Bonded Pairs vary

animal.description:
HI!! My name is Dot ! Im a 4 year old catahoula pup weighing just 40 pds. I love going on walks and I love practicing my commands .. especially with treats.. I’m potty trained but sometimes I have an accident when I get too excited . I’m also crate trained and I tend to go in it by myself when I want to take a nap and it has a fluffy pillow or blanket . At night I do prefer to sleep right beside my foster mom on the carpet. We tried the bed but my foster mom is a cuddler and I tend to get too hot so I usually move in the middle of the night . 

I love going on walks with my foster sister Raven . So I do very well with other dogs of all ages . I love when my foster dad gets home and wait for him at the door because he gives me lots and lots of pets and scratches behind my ear. 
My foster mom says I’m such a good and sweet girl and thinks I’m ready to find my forever home ! 

I am heartworm positive and going through slow kill treatment. You see I have lived outside all my life and was abused by my owners.  I was never given hw preventative which is a must in the South.  Please don’t let that prevent you from adopting me.  I will go through treatment and be as good as new and won’t let it slow me down.  

Please complete an application if you would like to meet me.
https://form.jotform.com/luckymutts/adoption-application

animal.description:
I was picked up in Sugar Land on 9/3/20 by Ft. Bend Animal Services. I don’t know how long I was homeless since I don’t have a calendar. I think it must have been a long time. Fortunately for me I have a Pup Squad microchip. I was spayed on 1/16/10 and I was about two years old then. So, best guess I am 12 years old. 

When I was found I had a hematoma in my left ear flap that was so large the flap was about an inch thick. I have had that repaired and my ears packed to get all of the yeast out. I don’t think my ear will ever match the other one but we can say that gives me character.

I don’t think I can hear because my foster mom has to get in my sight before I know what she wants. I love to eat and sleep and sit beside her in her chair. I’m easy peasy.

However, I am an alpha dog and will start a fight if I think one of the other dogs is too near the food container, a toy or whatever I perceive is mine. Not sure why I am this way. Maybe my last 10 years have not been kind in regard to other dogs. Because I am this way I need a home with no pets.

I walk great on a leash. I eat, sleep and stay in my house (crate) when no one is home. If out of my house, I will be your shadow!

Birdie's approx. DOB is 10/1/2008.

Our adoption fee is a $250.00 donation to Pup Squad Animal Rescue. Our adopted dogs are all spayed/neutered, vaccinated and micro-chipped. If you are interested in adoption, please go to www.pupsquad.org/adopt to read more about our policies and find our application. Applications should be submitted via the online form http://pupsquad.org/adopt/adoption-application.html.

During COVID 19 - We may not be able to help coordinate transport out of state due to limited resources on our end and limited transport options to get the dogs to destinations outside of Texas.

Thank you for choosing to rescue an animal in need!
www.pupsquad.org

***Before you send us an inquiry, consider if you are actually serious and READY to adopt.   *We also only adopt within a 2-hour driving distance of Goshen, IN. ***
**

Meet James Brown!!!  A gorgeous hunk of hound looking for a forever family.  James is turning 6 this week and is currently enrolled in the TGIE program being obedience train.   James will be graduating in January, he is a rockstar in the program and a staff favorite.    James successfully finished heartworm treatment prior to going to the TGIE program.  He has a helicopter tail and can jump like a kangaroo!  .  James will be officially available for adoption when he graduates.  If you are interested in James please contact Greyt Angels at greytangels@gmail.com or 574-535-3210.  

Please know we are not a shelter and are NOT open to the public. All meet and greets are arranged only AFTER an application is submitted and reviewed.
***
We LOVE the support and interest of every inquiry on our hounds!!! This enables us to better provide support to our adopters and our hounds, when needed, for a more successful adoption experience!

animal.description:
Introducing this darling sweet little mother daughter duo, Mally and Leola! These two girls came into rescue after their owners surrendered them and several other dogs to a dog pound. They were not in a position sadly where they could care for them any longer, and didn’t appear to care for them well while they had them. All of them were afraid but especially the mother, Mally. This girl was so terrified after being surrendered with all of her babies. While Mally is a mom, she is still a youngster, estimated at 18-24 months. Her oldest daughter is Leola who is closer to 12 months old and the two of them are so incredibly bonded. She also had another litter of puppies that were babies, only about 3 months old at the time. Everything was done to ensure that these guys went into foster care as soon as possible. All of Mally’s babies found wonderful forever homes. She found so much comfort and confidence with Leola that we decided it was important to keep them together. It is obvious that Mally has had a very difficult life and has very low self-esteem with new people and new settings, having Leola with her helps her very much.

We insured that all of their medical work was completed, and now they are waiting for their forever home! They live in a loving foster home together with a kitty and 3 other little dogs and they have blended in cheerfully and are so grateful to be in a kind, warm home where they can enjoy the simple peace of sweet humans and an easy going environment. 
Because they are unsure of new people, and have a preference of women, we are looking for a forever home with no children where there will be a loving mother figure. In their foster home they are wonderful with their foster daddy too! But it took him some time to earn their trust. Now that they have settled in, they have a wonderful routine! They are super easy going, wonderful pups to have around! Leola is especially cuddly, and they are fabulous! They are happy to trot outside to their fenced yard to go potty, and wait patiently for their parents to come home from work and they greet them with a wagging tail and big smiles! They don’t get into mischief when they are left alone and are happy to just snuggle up together on the sofa when they aren’t playing or exploring. 
Mally and Leola are looking for a home with nurturing, patient parents and a fenced yard. They will do just fine with or without other dogs or kitties! Their main goal is just a easy going, committed home who can appreciate these two youngsters didn’t have an easy start and crave a peaceful home life where healthy meals, plush bedding, relaxation and love are in abundance! They probably aren’t ideal for city life or people who want to bring their dogs to cafes or dog parks. They will be happiest with parents who are more  homebodies who enjoy an evening snuggling on the couch being outside enjoying the fall breeze and foliage. 

Mally and Leola need parents who long to teach pups how good life can be and that there are fabulous humans in this world who will teach them about love, stability, and what a safe, positive home is all about! If you would love to give these girls the future they long for and deserve, please visit our website and submit an application for adoption today! www.greatdivideanimalrescue.org

animal.description:
Willow is a 42 pound spayed female shar pei. She was born with front leg defects, but dont tell her because she gets around fine...on her front elbows. She looks as if she is doing a permanent play bow and runs around the home with her siblings just fine.

Willow can be friendly with strangers (if she feels safe with her person around) and loves treats and toys. She does bond to her one adult (she appears to prefer women to men) and does well with well mannered young kids. She knows how to use a dog door!

Willow likes to sleep in bed with you and is used to two dog beds/mats stacked beside the bed so she has a launching pad and cushion to jump up and down on her own. She needs a boost to get into car but will jump out on her own (best to keep a towel or mat handy so she can land softly).

Willow is NOT a fan of a leash, other than a slip lead for an annual vet visit, she will fight a leash. Her ideal home will have a dog door and a yard (so she doesn't have do be walked to potty), one or two stories (ideally carpeted stairs), a female owner with or without dog savvy kids or grandkids. Yes, pretty specific, but she will be your couch buddy, bed buddy and snuggler.

Willow is eating kibble, but loves a bit of broth, bacon fat, a bit of leftovers on top to make it oh so much tastier! 2/2/21 4:21 PM

animal.description: Remington AKA Remmy is a 2 yrs old brindle and white 85 lbs Bulldog/Pit Bull mix AKA a gentle giant. He has the most amazing green eyes. This boy is solid. He is a fast learner. At first when I went to put a harness on him he would have none of that. But after letting him decide when, he let me put the harness on without any problems. He does have a big head but once he allowed it the harness went right over it. He gives great kisses and thinks he's a lap dog. He does get nervous around strangers but if you give him time and don't rush he does good. It only took him a couple of hours when he let me walk him, he walks great on a leash. He comes with his own kennel. He loves his ears rubbed, to play fetch and chew on his bones. Unfortunately no cats or children. This is an amazing boy who is looking for his forever home. He will be completely vetted on 10/1/2020 and ready to go to his forever home. Apply at fromforgottentoforever.com/adoptionapplication/.

animal.description:
Momma is in foster and has made some wonderful progress. Here is what we have noticed about her: she is excellent with all other dogs, both small and large and enjoys their company. She is house-trained. 

Momma settles very well in the house both during the day and at night and she will let you sleep in. Momma is loyal - she will take some time to bond, but when she does, she will show you how happy she is to see you, even if you are just returning from another room in the house:)

She is calm, mild mannered, easy going and would perfectly suit a person or family that doesn't have time for a high-energy pup. Momma will need a family with a well-fenced yard as she is still learning to walk on a leash and enjoys laying out in the sun during the day. 

Momma is one sweet, gentle, shy girl. She has not been cat tested but we would not be surprised if she was fine with a cat companion. Please reach out if you think you may have a home for Momma and we will put you in touch with her foster family.

animal.description:
You MUST fill out an application on the Carolina Hearts website (link below) to be considered for adoption. Due to a large volume of calls and emails, we can ONLY ensure responses to those who fill out an application on the Carolina Hearts website (link below).

http://carolinaheartsrescue.org/adoption-information/

AVAILABLE: Vesper **HERDER EXPERIENCED HOME REQUIRED**

NO: children, female dogs, small pets, or livestock

Vesper, from James Bond, means evening in Latin. Vesper was bought as a cute little merle puppy by a loving family that was mesmerized by a cute fluff ball with ice blue eyes. Unfortunately, as she grew up they realized that Aussies aren’t the breed for them and their growing family which led to their decision to surrender her to rescue. 

Vesper can be slow to warm up to strangers, but once she has she does bond quickly to her person. She can be quite reserved with strangers to her home and will bark when new folks initially enter or drive up. Vesper does well with the little female dogs in her foster home, but butts heads with the resident Aussie gal. She does tolerate her male Aussie foster sibling, as long as he is respectful. 
Vesper has a VERY high prey drive and is not suitable for a home with cats, chickens, or other “prey-like” pets. Vesper enjoys escaping fences and cannot be left unattended, fortunately she does have very good recall and comes back when called. She is fairly high energy and WILL REQUIRE a herding dog savvy home WITHOUT children or small animals that will help her use her energy and smarts for good, not evil. She would likely excel dog sports. Vesper listens well, knows basic commands, is good on a leash, and loves car rides. 

Vesper is more than just a pretty face and will need a home that will continue to work with her to trust men and strangers and to work to exercise her mind and body. She is two years old, spayed, UTD on vaccines, microchipped, and on heartworm preventatives. Vesper is currently fostered in Pittsboro, NC and her adoption fee is $300. 

If you are an approved applicant and are interested in Vesper please contact the adoption committee. If you are interested and not yet approved please visit our website for adoption procedures and application.

In response to the social distancing recommendations from the CDC and WHO, the Roanoke Valley SPCA is modifying our adoption procedures. With these new restrictions, we do our best to be as fair as possible. Pets are adopted on a first come basis. Our challenge is to find homes for the pets in our care as quickly as possible so we can help other pets in need. With the increase in cases in Southwest Virginia, adoption hours are Thursday-Saturday between Noon and 7 pm. Unfortunately, we are unable to hold pets nor guarantee a pet will be available at the time of your appointment, but we do promise to call you if a pet is adopted prior to your appointment.

animal.description:
Sophia came to our rescue from Louisiana after a hurricane damaged the mobile home she was living in. Her owner turned her over to rescue along with 8 other siblings. Sophia is about 6 years old and weighs about 7 1/2 pounds. Her mother was a Pomeranian and her father was a chihuahua, so Sophia is a pomchi mix. According to the previous owner, Sophia never left the trailer and never saw anyone but her. She was not potty trained to go outside, but she's doing really well now with pottying outside. She does use potty pads inside, if needed. We are also working on leash training since she had never worn a collar or harness. She's such a good girl and very easy to care for. Sophia gets along well with other dogs, and will occasionally play. She does okay with our cats. She is okay with older children, but younger active children make her a little nervous and she hides. Sophia does warm up to her person after a few days, but she will need a patient and experienced owner to give her the time that she needs. Once she trusts you, she loves to be on your lap and cuddle. She will stand up on her hind legs when she's waiting for a treat...so cute. Sophia will be a wonderful companion for someone who wants a sweet, quiet little girl. Sophia has been spayed, is heartworm negative, had a dental, and has been updated on her vaccinations. She would love a new home where she can settle in and feel safe and comfortable.
In order to adopt, you need to send an e-mail to rescue@secondchancepoms.org asking for an application.  After you send this back, we will check references and someone will visit you in your home to discuss adoption.  We ask a donation of $425 for adults, which includes an applicable Texas sales tax, and $475 for puppies, which includes an applicable Texas sales tax.  This covers shots, spay/neuter, and any medical treatment, such as de-worming. We do not ship our pomeranians, but an out-of-state adoption can still happen if the adopter comes to the Houston, TX area to pick up their pom.

animal.description:
Elmo is a 3 year old male pitty mix who came to our rescue from a kill shelter in SC. He has been with Tiny Cause Rescue since September of 2020 and has had very little interest. Whats not to love about this beautiful brindle boy?  He is a sweet loving boy who is very active with a nice with a side of silliness. Elmo just wants to be with his people. He walks terrific on a leash and looks to his walker for direction. He's crate trained, potty trained and friendly with other dogs but can be dog selective. NO CATS FOR ELMO. He likes kids but might be too much to live with little ones as he can be a bit of a bulldozer when excited (unintentionally of course). Elmo is doing excellent on learning to stay down, he knows how to sit, and hes working on learning how to lay down. Elmo really just wants to find his forever loving home. 
His adoption fee is $150.00 which includes being up to date on vaccinations including rabies & bordetella, microchipped, dewormed, on flea/tick preventative and neutered.
We are a FOSTER based dog rescue therefore there isn't one central location with open hours to see our available dogs. They are all in loving foster homes enjoying learning how to be a furry family member. If interested we only set up meet and greets AFTER approving adoption applications with interested adopters as to not waste anyone's time.
All current/past pets MUST be up kept to date on vaccinations as well as being spayed/neutered to adopt from our rescue.

animal.description: Zulu #6708 is a 4-year-old male, Bull Mastiff mix.  Give Zulu a chance to earn your trust and love; he’ll be your best friend ever. He is nervous and shy when you first meet him. He will definitely require patience and time with his new adopter(s) in order to gain his trust. But once he does trust you, he is a completely different dog. He has high energy and would love a large backyard to play in. He will do best in a quiet, low activity household; he doesn't like loud noises; because of this no children in the home.  Zulu is good with other dogs.  He is very treat-motivated and knows the commands: sit, stay, off, down and come. He walks great on a leash. He is eager to meet new dogs when out on walks. We are looking for an adopter with experience with scared dogs. . He weighs 95 pounds and is full grown. This pup is microchipped. We believe you can always teach an ‘old’ dog new tricks, so we highly recommend continued obedience training for this smart pup; it stimulates the dog's mind and establishes a good dog/adopter relationship. This pup, like all pups, should be on heartworm preventative; an ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure. If you are interested in adopting this dog, and are already approved to adopt through our organization, please contact dogs@lastchanceanimalrescue.org with the pup’s name and ID number in the subject line. OTHERWISE, please submit an adoption application online: http://www.lastchanceanimalrescue.org/adoptus.html E-mail dogs@lastchanceanimalrescue.org with questions. animal.description:
Blue is a joyful, energetic guy who would also VERY much like to lie on the couch with you. He has been known to take a running leap across the room to get in on some snuggles. When he’s happy (which is often - Blue is inclined to happiness), he grunts quietly like a small blue pig. Blue will make you laugh a lot, and sometimes it seems like he understands the jokes, too.

Blue is friendly and always politely pleased to meet new people (especially if they pet him), but he reserves his heart for his own people.  He is sensitive to what’s going on in the home, and knows when it’s time to play and when it’s time to check out and take a nap. He’s a smart dog, and learns quickly, especially when motivated by treats.

Blue is an athlete, strong and nimble and always up for a long walk or a romp. He is working on his leash manners and tends to pull and bark at bicycles and other dogs, especially if he sees more than one of those things in quick succession, so a quiet neighborhood would be best. His foster parents have been working on this with him and have brought him a long way, and we know with continued guidance he can only get better. He just gets so excited and engaged by the things around him that he forgets there’s a person at the other end of the leash. Because of this, Blue would benefit from a home with an enclosed yard where he can play and get his energy out before working on his leash walking. He will also need to be the only pet in the house, but don't worry he has enough personality to fit all your needs. 

Blue is house trained and sleeps calmly in a closed crate overnight. He prefers not to be separated from his beloved people, but is okay as long as he is given free range of the couch to nap while you’re away. Because of his leash-reactivity, Blue will do best in a home with a family that’s committed to working on consistent positive reinforcement training. In exchange, he will provide you with infinite snuggles, vigorous tail-wagging, and bounces of delight.

?6 years old-45lbs. My adoption fee is $180 and includes microchip, neuter, reduced-cost training class, 1 month pet health insurance, free veterinary exam, leash/collar, food sample, toy & treat packet.

animal.description:
Clark - Coonhound/Bloodhound - Male - 1.5 Years - www.twyla.org

If you'd like to know more about this dog please visit www.twyla.org

Meet Clark: This gorgeous Boy is a Bluetick Coonhound/Bloodhound (we think) and the vet estimates he is about 1.5 years old. Clark was found with his sidekick "Lewis" while exploring Kingwood unaccompanied, and was saved by a good Samaritan who contacted us. Clark is quite a typical hound - he is happiest when he can follow his nose and an hang out close to the other dogs in his foster home and his people. He is quite aloof and takes a while to make eye contact with a new person, but he keeps close tabs on the people he trusts - he's usually not far from them and positions himself in spot in the house that allows for maximum coverage of all people and dogs. He gets along with all dogs he has met so far, he plays with some and is content to parallel live next to others. He loves "his" people and politely greets strangers, but takes a little while to include newcomers into his circle. Despite his considerate size he is quite gentle and affectionate. He is also quite talented at squeezing past a person in an open door, so he is looking for a secure yard with a family that know how to keep him contained when the front door opens, he's quite the opportunist. 

Clark is pretty calm and is looking for a moderately active home to include him in lots of outings, but more important would be another similar-sized dog for him to bond to. With strong hound-genes he vocalizes dissatisfaction so he shouldn't be left alone for long periods of time, he needs adequate exercise, mental stimulation and training to be happy and to curb his interest in jail breaking. He has learned to run next to a bike and gets very very excited when he he sees the bike getting ready. Clark seems to be an experienced fence jumper and chain link fence under 7 feet do not contain him, so we are looking for a home with solid 6-7 foot wooden fencing and someone who is home a lot to monitor him. 

***Please note: All dogs are fostered in private homes of volunteers, so to meet a dog please fill out an Adoption Application on our website (http://www.twyla.org/adopt/our-adoption-process) so we may setup a private meetup with the dog or coordinate for an Introduction at the next general Adoption Meet and Greet (as listed on our website: (http://www.twyla.org/upcoming-events), as not all dogs attend all Meet and Greets***

animal.description: At this time, all dog adoptions are being conducted by appointment only. Please click the link on our Adopt page (by species) to make an adoption appointment.Hi there, I'm Kovu. Being at the shelter makes me very nervous, but the people that I trust are making it pretty comfortable. I am very shy and nervous at first, but once I trust someone, I'm super friendly and silly. I am a huge fan of belly rubs, and only my most trusted inner circle get to experience my joy in the rubbing of my belly. My friends say that my personality really starts to show once I start to trust someone, and I think they are right. Since coming out of my shell, I'm kinda bossy while playing with other dogs. I enjoy playing with dogs, but I would need to be the only dog in the home because I am not a fan a sharing my things. No human siblings either, they scare me too much. I'm absolutely a dog worth going out on a limb for, and I'm not just saying that because I'm a stunner. I'm saying it because I've got lots of love to give, and I do want a home to call my own.

animal.description: I'm Country! I am a 4 year old Terrier, German Shepherd Mix. I am looking for a special home to call my own as I have a few specific needs. I have Pica and have had two surgeries after eating things I shouldn't have, so objects must be kept out of my reach. I have seizures sometimes- I am on medication that helps reduce the frequency but they still do happen, so I am looking for a mature home with no younger children. I am a calm, loving, gentle giant. animal.description:
Petey is a special needs 4 month old English Bulldog puppy who was turned in to the shelter as a “stray.” In all likelihood, a breeder dropped him on the street or at the shelter because Petey couldn’t be sold as he suffers from Spina Bifida, a congenital abnormality in the spinal column, that is tragically more common in English Bulldogs than any other breed. The effects of spina bifida vary by individual case, so we feel grateful to report that Petey is walking and playing like a normal puppy, and quickly picks up on cues from his foster mom and other dogs (and cats) in the house. However, he is somewhat incontinent, which requires frequent trips outside, and also diapers. We have also experimented with acupuncture and other treatments for him. Good thing he’s cute though. Aside from incontinence, Petey is otherwise very low maintenance. 

His favorite spot is to lay on the cool kitchen floor while you cook or on the porch near the BBQ, and he is full of puppy kisses and snuggles. 

An ideal home will provide easy and frequent access outside, and work to understand Petey’s special needs. He would do well with in a home with or without kids and other animals.

Fill out an application for Petey on our website! NewOrleansBulldogs.com

animal.description:
Tucker is a 10-11 year old pit mix who who weighs about 60 pounds. Poor Tucker has just never been able to find a family who loves him unconditionally and can make a commitment to him! 

Tucker is a very laid back guy who enjoys lounging in the sun, napping and watching TV. He is also happy to go for runs or chase balls around the yard. Tucker does not care for other animals and does take his possessions at little too seriously at times. He would be successful in a quiet, adult only home where he can play when he wants to play and relax when he wants to relax. He is house trained and has very good house manners.


A reduced adoption fee of $100 does apply for Tucker, our seniors, special medical and behavioral needs dogs and other "slow to adopt" dogs! 

Augusta Dog Adoptions is an all- volunteer, foster- based rescue. We take applications online and are scheduling individual adoptions in the Waynesboro, VA area during the pandemic.  A $175.00 adoption fee ($300 for puppies under 6 months old) helps us take care of all the dogs we rescue. All dogs are spayed/neutered, tested for heartworm and tick borne diseases (if old enough), microchipped, and vaccinated for rabies (if old enough), distemper/parvo and bordetella. They are also treated for internal and external parasites. Many dogs also receive extensive medical care such as dental work and major surgeries. For more information and to apply to adopt, please visit www.augustadogadoptions.org

animal.description:
Oh sweet Sadie! This girl is so full of snuggles and love! However, she is very shy when it comes to meeting new people. She is extremely shy around men. 

Sadie is fearful of many things, she needs an owner that will help her continue to experience life and build her confidence. 

She is a lover of individual attention and of learning new things. She just need a PATIENT person to understand that so many things are new experiences for her.

Sadie needs a fenced yard! She also needs to have a female as her owner/main caretaker. She would do best in a home that doesn’t have loads of strangers stopping in. 

If you are ready for the absolute sweetest girl and have the time to help her, we would LOVE to meet you! 

Sadie is fully vetted- spayed, microchipped and current on vaccinations. She also comes with 6 weeks of positive reinforcement obedience training! Sadie's adoption fee has been sponsored. 

TO MEET SADIE YOU MUST FIRST COMPLETE AN ADOPTION APPLICATION!! 

Please visit hope-rescue.org to read about our adoption process and complete our adoption application.

animal.description:
Scout is part of the Army Litter - she is around 9 months old as of September 2020. They were feral so Scout will require a specific home and a longer trial period. Foster to adopt situations have proven to be successful for feral dogs.

Feral dogs require patience, stability, routines/structure and other canine siblings to build confidence and assure them that humans are ok. We also do not recommend younger children - feral dogs need calm households. And....Scout must have a fenced in yard. They are worth the wait......

ADOPT SCOUT!!!!! www.LuckyPupRescueSC.com The adoption fee is $250.00 and we require a vet check and home visit (virtual). Scout has been spayed, vaccinated, chipped, dewormed and current on monthly flea/tick and heartworm prevention.

animal.description:
Meet Chief, a Rottweiler mix who weighs about 80 lbs. He knows the 'sit' command and is considered to be a med-high energy dog. He seems to be a bit of a lady's man and prefers the company of female dogs over males! No cats. You can also watch for stories, pictures and videos about Chief on our Facebook page https://www.facebook.com/groups/40103261297/ Ask to meet him today!!
 
Adoption fee: $425
 
Adoption fees for all dogs/puppies include a $50 refundable training deposit. Complete your basic training program and provide a copy of the certificate within 4 months (120 days) of adoption and we will refund $50 of the original adoption fee.
 
All dogs/puppies have been fully vetted including spay/neuter, micro-chipping, worming, heartworm testing and preventative treatment, flea/tick preventative, and all required age appropriate vaccinations. As required by Wisconsin Act 90, all dogs will have received a veterinarian exam (CVI) within the past 30 days.
 
Our adoption process requires the submission of an application. Applications and Adoption Rules can be found on our website, on the "HOW TO ADOPT" tab at JRsPupsNStuff.org. Upon receipt of the completed application, we will process the application including: contact with your veterinarian and completion of a home visit. Please be sure to include the contact information for your vet as we will call. If your vet requires an information release, please be sure to contact them as soon as you submit your application. We are a group of volunteers with families and jobs, so please be patient and allow a few days for our response.
 
JR's Pups-N-Stuff Dog Sellers License 270089-DS

Hi I’m Oliver, I’ve had a hectic few months. I was previously adopted from a rescue by a nice lady who was my owner since??. I returned to the rescue after she suddenly became ill. Since then I’ve been in a foster home with my foster mom and her teenage foster daughter. I live with 2 senior Eskies, a Pyrenees, cats, and a pig (yes you read that right. I find her kind of annoying and weird but I tolerate it). You can always find me by my foster moms side. She calls me her shadow. I like to hang with Georgia a lot (15 y/o female Eskie). She is always with foster mom too so we’re her shadow doubles. 

Don’t let my age fool you, I turn 12 in November and I’m a 9lb spunky little guy. I do enjoy naps but also like to play with toys. I really like when my foster mom gives me treats, my favorite is baby carrots. I like to be picked up and carried around. I have my foster grandma trained to pick me up whenever she comes over ?. Foster mom says sometimes I do have issues with “demand barking” so I’m working on it. Oh, I’m also working on house training. I was trained before but with all the changes and being around many animals in a new place I will mark. I’m very good about wearing my belly band diaper in the house though. sometimes have a problem going #2. I don’t like being outside when it’s cold and might run back in too quick. Foster mom says I’m a quick learner and should get back on track with crate training. I just haven’t liked being in the crate here because all my siblings are out and about. 

I sleep in the bed with foster mom at night and like to cuddle up under the blanket. I am pretty fashionable too and have some shirts I like to wear. I wear a harness (collars aren’t good for me bc of the pressure on my trachea can make Me cough) and walk well on a leash. Foster mom says I have pretty good recall but she has caught me trying to be an escape artist in the backyard. One time she caught me right as I snuck out and started to explore the neighborhood (well, fields and a couple houses). She eventually caught upto me and picked me up. I didn’t think much of it but she got really scared and worried. She blocked off that part of the fence and I haven’t tried my escape tricks again. 

I like it here but it’s been a big adjustment and I can get worked up sometimes barking with the other dogs. Every time I bark my foster sister, the Pyr, runs to the window barking. Foster mom says I may be small but I sure can run things. So I’d like to go back to a home that’s a little calmer. If I had a companion like Georgia that would be nice. I don’t really like the cats and will chase them sometimes so I’d like to be in a home without cats too. Foster mom says I’m a very sweet and cute little guy that bonded quickly with her and feel safe having her as my person. So It would be great if I had a human who was home a lot to be my pal. Overall I’m a pretty go with the flow kind of guy. 

Oh and I’m proud to say I’ve done great and the vet and groomer. I didn’t like when they trimmed my nails -ugh so annoying- but they were so impressed with how well I did with my bath and drying off. I really showed off my fancy prance after I got all clean and fluffy. 

*Will get car sick but not if he’s given the homeopathic medicine before a trip (30-60 mins before). I will donate some to go with him to his forever home. 
*Health: has the heart murmur and the other chronic issue that might flare up and need meds. He’s very good about taking his pills with peanut butter, also has the issue where is leg/knee will move out of place (I can’t remember the details exactly, my Vet mentioned it at the first visit but said it’s common in small dogs and not a big deal)

animal.description:
Hey Wisconsin, I'm ready to find a home to call my own. I've been here since the beginning of June, but needed some extra TLC before I started looking. I'm a 1 yo Carolina Dog Mix, also known as a Dingo, which means I'm 45 pounds of energy. Before I tell you about my time in WI you need to know a little bit about my Alabama life. My sister and I were left on a back road as puppies, so there was very minimal interaction with humans. The little time I saw them was not a good experience, however SPR sent some angels out to save us. After 2 months of trying to catch us with a live trap, we were finally caught. Shortly after that I came to WI to for more one on one time with a loving family in their home.
In my foster home I'm enjoying the joys of getting pets, playing with stuffed toys and Wisconsin cheese. I'm potty trained and do good in my kennel. I found out the kennel is a safe place to be if something startles me. My leash skills are good, but my foster mom will tell you in the beginning that I get excited so I will pull a bit. The best is when my foster dad takes me for these runs. Sometimes I wear him out! Hehehe. There is also a 13 year old girl in the house. She has been very patient with me. But no young kids for me as they are quick and sometimes loud so it scares me. My new home must be very patient with me as new things can be overwhelming. My foster home also has this dog that is showing me how wonderful life can be. I'm a monkey see monkey do kind of dog, so a confident dog in my new home is a must. Another thing that is a must is a martingale collar. That way if I get scared and pull I won't slip out. My fosters can explain this to you. A six foot high fenced in yard is very ideal for me since I'm an energetic pup yet. If you feel you are the right fit fill out an application at sandipaws.org thank you for taking time to read about me.
Thank you for your interest in a Sandi Paws Rescue, Inc. Please visit our site at sandipaws.org for more information on our organization or to fill out an application to adopt one of our pets. You can find information for volunteering o. our site as well.

She is very eager to please and would do well in obedience training. She would do best in a fenced in yard. LEONA'S ADOPTION FEE IS $170

*Due to Covid 19 restrictions some of our new intakes vet scheduling has been delayed. We will still go ahead and schedule your meet and greet even if all the vetting needed has not been completed. Once vetting is complete the approved adopter will be able to take their dog/cat home to their forever home.The shelter software system requires that we choose a predominant breed or breed mix for our dogs. Visual breed identification in dogs is unreliable so for most of our dogs we are only guessing at the dog's predominant breed or breed mix. We strongly encourage you to select your new pet by looking at each dog's individual personality and pet qualities rather than relying on a breed label that is only our best guess.

Our adoption fees vary from $150 and up. All of our dogs are up to date on vaccines, heart worm preventives, and flea/tick medication, and will be spayed/neutered prior to adoption. Portions of your adoption fee also help care for the sick and injured animals that we take in. Thank you for supporting us and considering a rescue dog!

animal.description:
He may not know Jiu Jitsu but Leonardo the Ninja Turtle is an expert at loyalty. 

Leo (aka Turtle) spent his first days after entering the rescue hospitalized in critical condition. After multiple surgeries he went to a temporary medical foster, they worked on building trust with treats and food. After recovering from his last procedure Leo was able to transfer to a longer term foster home. 

In Leo's current foster home he lives with dogs, cats and birds. 
His foster mom understands that patience is a virtue, their bond grows stronger with each day. He has been enjoying playtime & snuggles with a variety of sizes of canines from Great Danes to Chihuahua mixes. 

Leo does well with confident cats who are part of the pack but can go into typical terrier "chase mode" when seeing a kitty dart across the room. 

He LOVES to strut his stuff on walks & hikes. 

His Instagram hashtag is #LeonardoTheNinjaTurtleDog

Leo takes a minute to warm up to new people but seems to gravitate to women. He is working on building confidence with men and would NOT be well suited for a home with young children.
animal.name: Leonardo The Ninja Turtle (Popeye)

I met Roxy today! She is a complete and total delight! Her foster mom and Roxy met me at the park and we had so much fun watching Roxy explore. Roxy is ~5.5 yrs. old, an adorable Staffordshire Terrier mix saved from a miserable life of breeding. Rescue Ridge stepped up to save her and she is doing great in her foster home. Roxy loves people of all ages. She is affectionate, well-mannered, and kind. Roxy has great house manners and is fully housebroken/ crate trained, and is a pleasure to have in the foster home. She takes toys, treats, food gently, and is treat motivated. Roxy will give you her paw in exchange for a nice treat. She loves car rides, too! In the home, she is a terrific snuggler so turn on some movies and spend quality time with a truly loving girl. Roxy walks fairly well on a leash, just excited when she sees a squirrel LOL or another dog. Roxy loves to go for walks so put on your walking shoes and have a great time with Roxy! She prefers to be your one and only pet and with such a loving nature you truly won't need more. Please apply to adopt Roxy in central NJ at
Rescueridge.com
and if your application is a possible match a volunteer will get back to you within 72 hours. Here is Roxy's video
https://youtu.be/b1HoeRAS2-8debut
Please adopt Roxy. You won't regret it for a minute.

The standard minimum donation for puppies is $325 + 8.25% tax = $351.81, for dogs over 12 months the adoption fee is $225 + 8.25% tax = $243.66 and for our senior dogs 8 years and up is $100 + 8.25% tax = $108.25; this increase includes sales tax recently required by the State of Texas to collect. You can view all the adoptable pets and fill out an adoption application online on our website at http://dallasdogrrr.org.

Applications can be done at www.adoggie4you.org This dog is between 3 and 4. She is Heartworm positive, she starts her 2nd round of treatment on 12/15/2020. She will go out with meds. She weighs 15.4 pounds. Her adoption fee is $250

Little Mama is a playful dog with people. Her favorite game is playing keep away. She is a wiggle worm when you try to carry her. But she is very loving when you are sitting with her. She is good with children.

Little Mama is an alpha dog. She does boss around the other dogs. If she is put with an alpha, she will start arguments and fence fighting. Overall she is a good dog that would be in a family or single person home with no dogs or a submissive dog.

animal.description:
Liesl is such a special girl in so many ways!

She is a black lab mix, around 2 years old. She has lots of energy, plays well with others, and fits right in with her 4 canine foster siblings. What makes her so special is what she is a parapeligic pup! She gets around the house and yard scooting, and on walks she uses her wheels, and she has a chariot which helps with transport (these will go to her forever home with her).
She doesn't let her legs slow her down, and loves running in the yard with her friends!
She does need some assistance going potty, but is such a doll.

Liesl's perfect home will be someone who looks beyond her additional needs and understands you will get 110% back in love and attention - for the extra energy she will need in her daily routine. While her foster family loves her to the moon and back, there are more special cases like her that they want to continue to help with.

As a POPB adoptable, Liesl is eligible for 5 free obedience classes with her new family! We have adoption events every Saturday from 10 am to 1 pm at Petco in Gainesville, at 6869 W. Newberry Rd. (near the mall) and at the Millhopper Petsmart, 4119 NW 16th Ave. We also have special events regularly. Please visit our Facebook page (facebook.com/plentyofpitbulls) for information about upcoming events. For more information about our adoption process and a link to our application, please see popb.org/adopt

animal.description:
BIO: PRINCESS, 10 year-young female GSD ISO of my "person" for the new year ? 

Hello! WOOF! My name is Princess, and that I surely am! I am a super-sweet velcro 65-pound GSD being fostered at a home in Ventura, CA for SPARC (Santa Paula Animal Rescue Center). I live with two older retriever packmates and whilst I am very happy in my foster home, I really want to find *my* person/people. Please note: adoption will be through SPARC; her shelter listing is here: 
http://ws.petango.com/webservices/adoptablesearch/wsAdoptableAnimalDetails.aspx?id=45599236&css=http://ws.petango.com/WebServices/adoptablesearch/css/styles.css&PopUp=true) 
With reasonable notice, my foster mom is willing to transport me to SLO for a meet and greet once you are approved by the shelter.

Background:
I am an OTI due to no fault of my own. My elderly owner passed away and her son took me in, though he did not want me in the house so kept me in the yard without enough food, exercise or socialization to thrive (duration unknown), then turned me into SPARC in late September 2020. A friend of the shelter put out the call for a volunteer and my foster mom stepped up 10/10/20, as I was not doing well at the shelter -- I was very stressed and sad and shut down. My foster knew that I could be rehabilitated both emotionally and physically with the right environment and calm, happy packmates.

My furfriends really helped me come out of my shell and get comfortable with the nice life in a home outside of the scary shelter (the staff were very friendly and understanding, I am just not a good candidate for kennel life with high-energy dogs barking all the time - they make me very nervous). When coming into foster care, I was underweight, had ongoing skin and ear issues, had a ton of fur loss, and needed to be walked with the support of a sling as I have spondylosis (a fused spine). Within the first hour of being in my current foster home, I relaxed and took a well-needed snooze within feet of my new foster fur brother and sister. We dropped the sling after the first week, as I was able to gain muscle mass with increasingly longer walks and physical exercises to make me strong. Despite my underlying structural condition, I am able to do everything my pack mates can: I go up and down a few stairs in my one-story home, I can get in and out of the car without aid, and can walk, trot and run with relative ease (although the latter can be a little "clumsy" sometimes due to my spinal issues). Nothing stops me! I have a great amount of go for my age and gusto to explore. My fur has all grown back in (and some of it is kind of wooly, rather cute if I may say so myself).

Here are the fabulous things my foster mom knows about me:
I am housetrained and I will wait by the back door to go out if it is not open
I sleep well through the night on a dog bed
I eat my breakfast and dinner like a champ
I walk well on a leash, though am strong and can pull if I see something that I would like to chase
I love car rides
I love belly rubs and rolling upside down in the grass at the park
I have a pretty high prey drive so I don't think that kitties, birds or other furries will be good housemates for me
I enjoy my medicated baths, and "accept" my weekly ear flushing
I am friendly with all of people I have met on my walks and coming into my foster home, and I am quiet with my greetings (no jumping, barking, etc.)

My foster mom thinks I will do best in a home with calm, older pack mate(s), or with a person who is home a lot. I exhibited a fair bit of separation anxiety when my foster mom left the house, but we worked on that together and now I am fine and just wait on my dog bed in the front window for her to return home. I have not been left on my own without one or both of my fur pals. My foster mom walks me separately in the morning for my "long" walk (approx. a mile and a half) so that I can get used to being out on my own. I am definitely more nervous alone than on my afternoon "short" walks (approx. 4-8 blocks) with my 2 pack mates.

I am not a good candidate for a home with balance-compromised owners, young kids who might climb on me, or exuberant / high energy dog pals.

I react in-kind to dogs' energies ... calm, soft posture, tail wagging, I do the same. Exuberant or high-energy dogs, I bark and lunge and think that it is appropriate for me to try to engage with snapping teeth (foster mom's note: this does not strike me as "aggressive", just rather an unsocialized response, Princess was very mouthy with me to begin with and we have curtailed the mouth on my hands).

I exercise on-leash only and have been working hard on "leave it" (cats, high-energy dogs) then my foster Mom calls my name and I turn to look at her, sit, get a treat, and calm down before we continue our walk.

I do not have resource guarding issues, I live with, eat, exercise and take treats with my 2 packmates.

I love to take multiple daily walks but am not a running/hiking or dog park partner.

I think I did not have a lot of boundaries in my original home, my attitude is "I want what I want when I want it!" so my foster mom has been working on "leave it", not door dashing, sitting for treats, waiting my turn for treats, etc. I am very smart and most definitely a "people-pleaser", so I will continue to do well with an owner who is willing to keep up my training / socialization.

According to the vet at SPARC, I should have my ears flushed with a medicated wash once a week, continue to have regular (1-2x/month) medicated baths and am taking Carprofen and Gabapentin daily.

Please get in touch if you are interested in a super-friendly older pup who wants nothing more than to chill with her person and please you. WOOF! DOG LICK!

animal.description:
A lovely lady looking for lots of love!

Lola joined us at Friends For Life after being found as stray along with her newborn puppies.  This sweet girl has been such a wonderful mama to her babies and she is ready to be loved as much in return now that her pups are all getting settled in their forever homes.  

Lola is lovely! This darling girl is gorgeous. With her milk-chocolate colored fur and her caramel colored eyes, one look at Lola and it’s clear that she is a sweetie pie through and through. 

Lola is learning! After spending some time as a stray, Lola is learning all there is to know about being a family dog. Her favorite hobby is to go on walks and explore the great outdoors.  She has been hard at work practicing her leash manners so that she can go on lots of adventures with her new family!

Lola is loyal! She can be a bit shy at first but once she warms up she is yours forever. With her easygoing personality and mellow temperament, Lola will fit in great in most homes.  She has come so far in her time at the shelter and a fresh start in a new home is exactly what she needs. 

Lola would thrive in a home that is willing to be patient with her as she adjusts and adapts to her new surroundings.  With calm and kind people around her, Lola will flourish in her new home and return the love she receives tenfold. If this sweet pup sound like the right fit for your home, apply to meet Lola today!

animal.description:
Meet Horn, a 5 year old, 73 lb., tricolored treeing walker coonhound. Horn is a very sweet boy, looking for a family to adopt and love; he has a great personality!
 
Heres what he wants to tell you:

Hi! I am very lively, happy, and love to be close by with my foster family. In fact, I like to keep close with them in the house, just to make sure they dont get lonely. They say Im the sweetest, gentlest dog, and want to please. I love to be around people, get petted, go on walks and be a loyal companion. I dont really like to be left alone very much and can do a bit of howling. Because of that, I would do best in a single family home or maybe a townhouse; apartment living is not for me.
 
I want to run and play a lot so need tons of walks and exercise. I love to play with other dogs, so playdates and trips to the dog park will be great for me even if I dont have a doggy sibling. Human siblings would be great too! I'd be great with kids, both large and small.
 
They think I may have been an outdoor dog before, and love to be outside hanging out on the deck where I can watch and monitor the neighborhood. My favorite activity is taking walks. I am starting to figure out how to walk on a leash but there are so many exciting smells on my walks, that its just too exciting sometimes! Riding in the car is also exciting, although long rides are boring so I tend to get impatient and whine when I have to ride for a long time. I just want to get out and explore!

I quickly learned house manners and where everything is (especially the kitchen!). 
 
My dream is to adopt a family that can provide lots of love and Ill provide lots of love in return!

Check our more pictures and videos of me here: https://www.dropbox.com/sh/yzr919vgpcptfhf/AAAvRuE48_DIlf4ePtrFVD35a?dl=0

PAW places animals in the Washington DC Metropolitan area only.

animal.description:
Lexi came to us from a local shelter as she was so scared to come away from the wall her chances of being adopted were slim. She is between 1.5 – 2 years old and ready to start her life. Lexi is a fun and eager puppy who thrives on the attention and love from her people. She is super shy at first but after she gets use to you, she is a super happy girl who loves to play with her people and dog friends. She is now starting to explore new places on foot, and is ok with short car rides, long car trips are not good. Lexi has great house manners is crate trained and can relax hanging out. Lexi will blossom with a confident and experienced handler. We are looking for a home with a woman and no children. She has been afraid of most men but not all – so it all depends on how she feels about you if you are male. Her timid yet loving personality is contagious and everyone who patiently takes the time to meet her, falls in love. She is looking for a strong and competent companion who will guide and support her to build up her confidence. We are recommending at least one visit with her at her foster home where she is most comfortable. If all goes well, we will bring her to your home.

Please visit our website at http://www.gsror.com/adoptionapp/ to complete an online application.

animal.description:
Medical notes:  I am positive for Lyme and Ehrlichia. I will need to be on 28 days of doxycycline (an antibiotic). I will need a grain and potato free, fish-based food.

One fish, two fish, red fish, blue fish, and now the BEST Fish… Thats ME!! I am 5 years old and 40 lbs of cuteness! (I am very energetic for an older guy.)
 
Are you looking for a snuggle buddy? A walking buddy? A playmate for another dog? I am your guy! I do it all - some I do a little better than others, but I can learn! Just give me a little time to get used to my new home. 

I am a really easy dog and super sweet. I like being outside and will stand at the door until you let me out even if I just came inside, but when I am tired out I will happily crash on any soft spot. I love finding and lounging in a sunny patch in the yard. I can use the doggy door like a pro and have no interest in jumping any fences even if deer are on the other side. I love walks, but I recommend you get an easy walk harness for me so I can learn to be a better walker and not just move move move. 
 
If you pay attention to me, I have perfect potty manners. I do believe I would be good for a family with another dog and fenced in yard because of my love for playing and the being outside! That is not to say that I can’t be an only dog, but I might look bored or lonely, so you might have to entertain me a bit. I can be mouthy and may grab your hand or arm during rough/excited play. I DO NOT bite down or break the skin, but to a young child, I could be startling. I easily correct and you can move my attention onto a toy.

I don’t really play catch, but I like squeaky toys. When I am not playing or spending time outside I love to sleep and snuggle right up with you on the couch or on my dog bed. I love to wrestle with my big doggy friends that currently live with me. We will play for HOURS and then fall asleep inside or outside. I will happily play with my tiny dog friends, but I can forget how big I am and can be a bit rough, so we only play fully supervised. There is no aggression - just lots of paws, chasing and jumping. 

I love mealtime and am a big fan of the smoked duck feet from Dog Krazy! Although I am very food driven, I behave in the kitchen if I am not left alone. There are just so many good smells up on the counter I might be tempted to investigate when you are not looking. I will not bother you during your dinnertime.  

I am GREAT in a crate and sleep there all night without a peep! Night can be scary to me. If I am startled awake I have been known to bite. So for everyone’s safety, my forever family needs to be willing to let me sleep in the crate at night. Please respect my need for space at night, while I am not proud, I did bite the son and Dad in my last home at night.

You can come adopt me or even join our foster program to help the humans learn all the awesome things about new dogs like me! Learn more on our website!

Hope to see you soon! 

Educational articles:
3/3/3 Rule;
https://www.rescuedogs101.com/bringing-new-dog-home-3-3-3-rule/?fbclid=IwAR2iv5m7fqk3FieO7LOsstGeGsYYV_F1rJOd1BPxaImofLpcinpYsUbFRWs

Adoption Donations are $250 for an adult, $350 for puppies (a dog under one year of age), and $125 for a senior dog (based on the age of the dog). Adoption donations are to be made via cash, and credit/debit card. There is a $5 fee to run cards.

Please remember to bring a collar and leash (non-retractable) with you the day of the adoption. Note: Martingale collars and slip leads are strongly recommended.

Due to COVID19, we aren't having as many open, public adoption events.  Current schedule is pre-determined meet and greet appointments are Wednesday evenings and on Saturday from 12-2.  
Our adoption center is located at 3602 Lafayette Blvd, Suite 102, Fredericksburg, VA 22408. It's important that you keep an eye on your emails for any changes or updates during the adoption process.

Visit our website for an application to adopt. 
https://www.olddominionhumanesociety.org/adoption-application

Old Dominion Humane Society is a volunteer based organization. We are run completely by volunteers, who also have full time jobs, so we appreciate your patience.  Currently, the average timeframe for a response to your application is 1 week.

Like us on Facebook "Old Dominion Humane Society"
and be a part of promoting forever homes for dogs in need.
#Adopt #Donate #Foster #Volunteer 

Note: ODHS only adopts to Virginia and surrounding states (including D.C.). A $50 out of state fee applies.

**My post adoption training has been sponsored by Creative Canine Solutions! My adopters will receive a FREE virtual consultation with my adoption, and 10% off any additional training packages!**

Hi, I'm Seiva!

Do you like other dogs? I do not like dogs and cannot be around them

What do you think about cats? I have a high prey drive and should not live with cats

So how do you feel about kids? I can be pretty nervous with new people and should live with teenagers and older

What's your energy level like? About medium

Is there anything else we should know about you? I'm about 7 years old, and I weigh between 55-65 lbs. I have a behavior and medical waiver staff would be happy to discuss over the phone.

I came into the shelter as a surrender and the above information is all recommendations based on my previous history and the behavior seen at the shelter. Expect to learn more about me after adoption.

It is unknown how this animal will do in their new home as all animals can be different with each person. It is important to take this into consideration when thinking about adopting and making sure you are prepared to work with any potential medical or behavior issues that occur after adoption.

My adoption fee includes my spay/neuter, current vaccinations, permanent microchip identification, certificate for a free veterinary exam, post-adoption support and more!

Thank you for taking the time to learn a little about me! If you think we would be a good match call and ask about me! I'm looking for my forever home and it could be with you!

ADOPTION INFORMATION: If you live in the city of Eugene or in Lane County you will be purchasing a dog license in addition to the adoption fee. You will get to choose between a one year, two year, or three year license.
